abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. It is important to
            reinforce emergency reconstruction operations should not be
            combined with broad sectoral policy reform efforts. This
            project is a good example of a well conceived post-conflict
            reconstruction operation. However, the project's
            experience supports the guidance provided in OP/BP 8.50 on
            emergency operations, by showing how difficult it is to
            implement urgently needed rehabilitation investments, while
            simultaneously pursuing broader policy reforms in a number
            of sectors. Sectoral objectives require support from more
            focused interventions. Addressing these kinds of objectives
            in sectors ranging from education and health to electricity
            and agriculture was outside the competency of ARRA -
            Azerbaijan Agency for Rehabilitation and Reconstruction of
            Areas - which had been established to implement the narrower
            reconstruction program. Further lessons suggest that
            operations involving multiple donors must be carefully
            designed to allow for different agendas, financing
            arrangements, and funding timetables among donors; yet, also
            suggest that too narrowly limiting project beneficiaries may
            create additional social and political risks.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Pilot Reconstruction Project for
            Azerbaijan aims to finance the first phase of the program
            for the Resettlement and Reconstruction of the Liberated
            Areas, which a) facilitates the repatriation of internally
            displaced persons; b) establishes and strengthens
            institutions involved in the voluntary resettlement of IDPs,
            de-mining and the reconstruction of areas affected by the
            conflict; and c) assists in raising and coordinating support
            from international donors and nongovernmental organizations
            to raise the basic standard of living for IDPs. There are 6
            components: 1) supporting voluntary repatriation aided by
            establishing a relocation agency; 2) rebuilding/repairing
            housing; 3) creating employment and generating income
            through micro-credits for starting up small businesses; a
            small public works program; funding agricultural inputs,
            livestock, equipment, machinery, and on-farm demonstrations;
            providing land titles; rebuilding irrigation infrastructure;
            organizing water users associations; and improving public
            awareness; 4) financing structural repair and rebuilding
            health care facilities and schools; and procuring essential
            drugs, medical supplies and equipment, and school furniture;
            5) rebuilding and repairing infrastructure, and power
            transmission and distribution; and 6) enhancing the capacity
            of agencies involved in rehabilitating IDPs, in de-mining,
            and in reconstructing areas affected by the conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh.
